titlepage.titleproper: Register of the Nikolai Valentinov Papers, 1912-1964
titlepage.publisher:
Hoover Institution Archives
Stanford University
Stanford, California
titlepage.p: © 1998 Hoover Institution Archives. All rights reserved.

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, clippings, reports, and photographs, relating to Russian revolutionary movements and emigre life, Imperial Russian and Soviet agricultural and economic policies, labor movements, Menshevism, and political events in Russia.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Nikolai Valentinov Papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1965.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Enters Petersburg Institute of Technology, joins revolutionary movement and is exiled to Ufa
Returns from exile, studies at Kiev Polytechnic Institute, is arrested for revolutionary activities, escapes to Europe
Meets Lenin in Geneva, joins Social Democratic Party (Bolsheviks)
Returns to Russia, breaks with Lenin and the Bolshevik Party. Joins the Mensheviks
Begins lifelong engagement in journalism. Contributes to Russkoe Slovo and Kievskaia Mysl'. Resigns from Menshevik Party
Edits Torgovo-Promyshlennaia Gazeta, organ of the Supreme Council of National Economy of the U.S.S.R.
Emigrates to Paris, France. Publishes in emigré and French press
Author, Vstrechi s Leninym. English translation published in 1968 as Encounters with Lenin
Author, Dva Goda s Simvolistami. English translation published in 1969 as Two Years With the Symbolists
Author (posthumously), The Early Years of Lenin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists mostly of the correspondence and writings of Nikolai Vol'skii, also known under the pseudonyms Nikolai Valentinov and E. Iur'evskii. The collection covers the period of his emigration in Paris between 1932-1962. Of special interest is the first part of the collection, which includes his correspondence with fellow socialists in the emigration, (Mensheviks in particular). Also important is his correspondence with European and American scholars interested in the history of socialism and the Russian Revolution. The second part of the collection consists of typescript drafts of Valentinov's writings with holograph annotations, and an untitled holograph manuscript.

Consists primarily of correspondence on political subjects with fellow Russian socialists in the emigration, as well as with British and American scholars interested in the Russian revolutionary movement. Arranged alphabetically by name of correspondent
Typescript drafts of articles, an unfinished manuscript, and miscellaneous material used in the preparation of Valentinov's writings. Arranged by physical form and therein chronologically by title
Clippings from Russian emigré, Soviet, and French press. Arranged alphabetically by language of publication
Nine prints depicting Nikolai Valentinov and others
Membership cards for the Bibliothèque Nationale and the Association des Ecrivains Russes à Paris, 1958. Includes photographs

did.unittitle: Copies of Nikolai Valentinov's letters sent at his request by the International Institute of Social History, Amsterdam
American Committee for the Liberation of the Peoples of Russia (Vanda Pampukh), 1953-1958
1949-1959. Includes typescript with holograph annotations by Lydia Dan, entitled "Sotsialdemokratiia v rezoliutsiiakh londonskogo s"ezda"
Institut für Erforschung der Geschichte und Kultur der UdSSR e. V.
Shvarts, S. Includes correspondence with Chekhov Publishing House, 1952-1958
"Iz moei knigi Makh I Marksizm", n.d.
"Kak raspredelialsia v 1937 g. narodnyi dokhod S.S.S.R.", n.d.
"Men'shevizm I ego propaganda idei revoliutsionnogo samoupravleniia", n.d.
"La méthode suédoise ou la méthode soviétique?", n.d.
"Mozhno li verit' sovetskim ischisleniiam natsional'nogo dokhoda?", n.d.
"O frantsuzskoi revoliutsii 1936-1937: Chemu ona uchit?", n.d.
"Promyshlennost' v fevral'skuiu revoliutsiiu, gody voennogo kommunizma I period 1920-1923 g.g.", n.d.
Review of Vasilii Zen'kovski, Istoriia russkoi filosofii, n.d.
"Trotskistkaia oppozitsiia I bor'ba s neiu", n.d.
"Dovoennaia industriia eia uroven' I osnovnyia problemy", 1932
"Ob umiraiushchikh zamkakh I ischezaiushchikh burzhuaznykh kvartirakh", 1933
"Chudo na vostoke, piatiletnii plan I rozhdenie sovetskoi industrii", 1935
"Russkaia derevnia I sel'skoe khoziaistvo za period 1906-1917", 1937
"Domaine des trusts et de la nationalisation", 1945
Miscellaneous material entitled "Mirovaia revoliutsiia: Eia smysl, put', zakony", used in lectures, 1945-1946

scopecontent.p: One portrait print of Nikolai Valentinov, one portrait print of IU. Dalin, one print of Lydia Dan, one portrait print of A. Potresov, four prints of Sergei Prokopovich, and one print of Elena Stensel' (envelope A)
